messageBody:
>
> Thanks Erik,
> I am suprised that this (and equivalent tests for
> binary files) hasn't
> become
> a part of one of the base classes. Does anyone know why
> (time, philosophy,
> etc ) ?

My guess would be philosophy. (That DOES sound like a song title, doesn't
it? :-)

If you can only test your class by testing the output it generates on a
filesystem, its design could be improved. It should probably take an
OutputStream and write there. You can then compare the contents of the
OutputStream to your expected result.

It's all about keeping implementation details out of the public interface. A
file representation is an implementation detail - a stream is not.

One of the benefits you reap if you implement your classes that way is that
you can add MD5 checksums, compression, etc without any redesign. If your
class is writing directly to a file, you would have to modify that class to
achieve the same.

Of course, that's only a guess - I could be completely off :-)

>
> One of the most common situations for me in testing tools is
> the need to
> test a given file output against a canonical output file.

That is definitely true for acceptance tests. Unit tests should not pose
that problem.
